prevtext:
\title{Compact spaces as quotients of projective Fra\"{I}ss\'E limits}

\maketitle
\begin{abstract}
 We develop a theory of projective {Fra\"iss\'e}{} limits in the spirit of Irwin-Solecki, which moreover support a dual structure. Let $K$ be a zero-dimensional, second countable, compact space. We prove that a subgroup $G$ of ${\mathrm{Homeo}}(K)$ is closed in the compact-open topology if and only if it is the automorphism group of some dual topological {Fra\"iss\'e}{} limit ${\boldsymbol{K}}$ on domain $K$.
As an application we prove that every second countable, compact space is the quotient of a projective {Fra\"iss\'e}{} limit ${\boldsymbol{K}}$ with a closed equivalence relation on $K$ that is definable in ${\boldsymbol{K}}$.
\end{abstract}





\section*{Introduction}
The interplay between {Fra\"iss\'e}{} theory and dynamics of non-Archimedean Polish groups established by the correspondence between closed subgroups of $S_\infty$ and countable {Fra\"iss\'e}{} structures has been fruitful in many ways (see for example the survey \cite{survey}). Taking this fact as a departure point it is natural to seek  what would the natural correspondence be for projective {Fra\"iss\'e}{} structures.       

Projective {Fra\"iss\'e}{} structures were first introduced by T. Irwin and S. Solecki in \cite{Irwin}. These are zero-dimensional, compact, topological structures which provide a dual to the classical {Fra\"iss\'e}{} structures. However, the duality in \cite{Irwin} was not explicitly present in the structure as such but rather in the morphisms that were used in the amalgamating process. In the same paper they used the projective limit of finite, reflexive, linear graphs in language ${\mathcal{L}}_R=\{R\}$, where $R$ is a binary relation symbol, to provide a simple description of the unique hereditary, idecomposable, chainable continuum known as the pseudo-arc. This enabled them to deduce new results regarding the pseudo-arc and to show how previously known facts about it (e.g., projective universality and homogeneity) were linked at a deeper level. 


Since then, projective {Fra\"iss\'e}{} constructions were used by several authors in the study of compact spaces and their homeomorphisms groups e.g., \cite{Lelek}, \cite{Ample}, \cite{Large}. There is standard scheme in the analysis that appears in these papers. One starts with a second-countable compact space $Y$ where either $Y$ or the group ${\mathrm{Homeo}}(Y)$ is under investigation. Then one defines an appropriate class ${\mathcal{K}}$ of finite model theoretic ${\mathcal{L}}$-structures  which ``approximate'' $Y$. If this class ${\mathcal{K}}$ satisfies the ``projective {Fra\"iss\'e}{}'' axioms \cite{Irwin} then the projective {Fra\"iss\'e}{} limit ${\boldsymbol{M}}$ of ${\mathcal{K}}$ is uniquely defined. Since the domain $M$ of ${\boldsymbol{M}}$ is a zero-dimensional space one cannot expect to equate it with $Y$ which is in general not zero-dimensional. However, in all the cases cited above the structures appearing in ${\mathcal{K}}$ were classes of graphs perhaps with extra model theoretic structure added on top. The edge relation $R$ was part of the language ${\mathcal{L}}$ and in the limit ${\boldsymbol{M}}$ the relation $R^{{\boldsymbol{M}}}$ always turned out to be an equivalence relation. The quotient ${\boldsymbol{M}}/R^{{\boldsymbol{M}}}$ was equal to $Y$ and the map ${\mathrm{Aut}}({\boldsymbol{M}})\to{\mathrm{Homeo}}(Y)$ that was induced by the quotient was a continuous embedding with dense image in ${\mathrm{Homeo}}(Y)$. This allowed the study of $Y$ and ${\mathrm{Homeo}}(Y)$ via the combinatorial properties of the {Fra\"iss\'e}{} class ${\mathcal{K}}$.

The purpose of this note is to turn this observations to a general method. However, this is not always possible if we insist to use only classical model theoretic structure as done in \cite{Irwin}. We rewrite the theory developed in \cite{Irwin} dualizing it not only in the level of the morphisms but also in the level of structures i.e. we also allow dual predicates in ${\mathcal{L}}$ which quantify over dual tuples (finite clopen partitions). We will call a topological ${\mathcal{L}}$-structure purely dual if ${\mathcal{L}}$ contains only dual predicates.

In Chapter \ref{Chapter_closed_subgroups_of_Homeo} we use a standard orbit completion argument  (i.e., we add extra predicates; one for every orbit) and equipping ${\mathrm{Homeo}}(K)$ with the compact-open topology we get the following result.      

\begin{theorem*}[\textbf{\ref{theorem orbits}}]
Let $G$ be a closed subgroup of ${\mathrm{Homeo}}(K)$ where $K$ is zero-dimensional, compact, second-countable space. Then there is a purely dual projective {Fra\"iss\'e}{} structure ${\boldsymbol{K}}$ on domain $K$ such that ${\mathrm{Aut}}({\boldsymbol{K}})=G$. 
\end{theorem*}   

Theorem \ref{theorem orbits} should be thought of as the dual of the statement that wants every closed subgroup of $S_\infty$ to be the automorphism group of a classical {Fra\"iss\'e}{} limit. In Chapter \ref{direct to dual} we provide a method which allows to turn any topological ${\mathcal{L}}$-structure into a purely dual one without losing any information. We also show  that above theorem is false if we do not allow our structures to support a dual structure. Therefore the context of dual structures is strictly more general then the context of direct structures. 

 In Chapter \ref{Compact spaces} we fix a special binary  relation symbol $\mathfrak{r}$ whose interpretation will always be a reflexive and symmetric closed relation. This should paralleled with the  metric {Fra\"iss\'e}{} theory where the symbol $d$ is  reserved as a signifier for the metric.  A formal relational language ${\mathcal{L}}$ will be decorated with the subscript $\mathfrak{r}$ whenever $\mathfrak{r}$ belongs to ${\mathcal{L}}$. Therefore, we always have  $\mathfrak{r}\in{\mathcal{L}}_\mathfrak{r}$ and ${\mathcal{L}}_\mathfrak{r}$-structures are always in particular reflexive $\mathfrak{r}$-graphs. We say that an ${\mathcal{L}}_\mathfrak{r}$-structure ${\boldsymbol{K}}$ is a pre-space if $\mathfrak{r}^{{\boldsymbol{K}}}$ is moreover transitive and therefore an equivalence relation. We apply Theorem \ref{theorem orbits} to get the following result.

\begin{theorem*}[\textbf{\ref{compactSpacesMainTheorem}}]
For every second-countable, compact space $Y$ there is a projective {Fra\"iss\'e}{} pre-space ${\boldsymbol{K}}$ such that:

In this topology the group ${\mathrm{Aut}}{}({\boldsymbol{K}})$ of automorphisms of a dual topological ${\mathcal{L}}$-structure ${\boldsymbol{K}}$ is a closed subgroup of ${\mathrm{Homeo}}(K)$. To check this, let $g\not\in{\mathrm{Aut}}{}({\boldsymbol{K}})$. We will find an open neighborhood $V_g$ of $g$ in ${\mathrm{Homeo}}(K)$ which does not intersect ${\mathrm{Aut}}{}({\boldsymbol{K}})$. Since $g\not\in{\mathrm{Aut}}{}({\boldsymbol{K}})$, one of the following holds:
\begin{enumerate}
\item there is $R\in{\mathcal{L}}$ of arity say $m$ and a dual tuple $e\in m^K$ such that
${\boldsymbol{K}}\models R(e)$ if and only if ${\boldsymbol{K}}\not\models R(e\circ g^{-1})$, or
\item there is $r\in{\mathcal{L}}$ of arity say $m$ and a tuple $i\in K^m$ such that
${\boldsymbol{K}}\models r(i)$ but ${\boldsymbol{M}}\not\models r(g\circ i)$, or
\item there is $r\in{\mathcal{L}}$ of arity say $m$ and a tuple $i\in K^m$ such that
${\boldsymbol{K}}\not\models r(i)$ but ${\boldsymbol{M}}\models r(g\circ i)$.
\end{enumerate}

In the first case notice that if $g\not\in{\mathrm{Aut}}{}({\boldsymbol{K}})$ then there is $R\in{\mathcal{L}}$ of arity say $m$ and  
But then $V\big(e^{-1}(0),g\circ e^{-1}(0) \big)\cap\ldots\cap V\big(e^{-1}(m-1),g\circ e^{-1}(m-1)\big)$ is an open subset of ${\mathrm{Homeo}}(K)$ containing $g$ and lying entirely out of ${\mathrm{Aut}}{}({\boldsymbol{K}})$.

In the second case, because $r^{{\boldsymbol{M}}}$ is closed, we can find an open rectangle $U_0\times\ldots\times U_{m-1}$ around $\big((g\circ i)(0),\ldots,(g\circ i)(m-1)\big)$ which does not intersect $r^{{\boldsymbol{M}}}$. Therefore, let $V_g=V\big(\{i(0)\},U_0\big)\cap\ldots\cap V\big(\{i(m-1)\},U_{m-1}\big)$.

For the last case, notice that if we let $(b_0,\ldots,b_{m-1})=\big((g\circ i)(0),\ldots, (g\circ i)(m-1)\big)$, then, as in the previous case we can find open neighborhood $V_{g^{-1}}$ of $g^{-1}$ such that for every $f\in V_{g^{-1}}$, $f(b_0,\ldots,b_{m-1})\not\in r^{{\boldsymbol{M}}}$. Let then $V_g=V_{g^{-1}}^{-1}=\{f^{-1}: f\in V_{g^{-1}}\}$. Using the continuity of the inversion operator $f\to f^{-1}$ in $\tau_{\mathrm{co}}$ we have that $V_g$ is open and moreover $g\in V_g\subset{\mathrm{Aut}}{}({\boldsymbol{K}})^c$.


The following theorem says that the inverse of the above observation is true, i.e., for every closed subgroup $G$ of ${\mathrm{Homeo}}(K)$ there is topological ${\mathcal{L}}$-structure ${\boldsymbol{K}}$ on $K$ such that $G={\mathrm{Aut}}{}({\boldsymbol{K}})$. Moreover, ${\boldsymbol{K}}$ can be taken to be purely dual and projectively ultra-homogeneous.


\begin{theorem}\label{theorem orbits}
Let $G$ be a closed subgroup of ${\mathrm{Homeo}}(K)$. Then there is a purely dual projective {Fra\"iss\'e}{} structure ${\boldsymbol{K}}$ on domain $K$ such that ${\mathrm{Aut}}({\boldsymbol{K}})=G$. 
\end{theorem}

Let then $V_g=V_{g^{-1}}^{-1}=\{f^{-1}: f\in V_{g^{-1}}\}$. Using the continuity of the inversion operator $f\to f^{-1}$ in $\tau_{\mathrm{co}}$ we have that $V_g$ is open and moreover $g\in V_g\subset{\mathrm{Aut}}{}({\boldsymbol{K}})^c$.

Let $G$ be a closed subgroup of ${\mathrm{Homeo}}(K)$. Then there is a purely dual projective {Fra\"iss\'e}{} structure ${\boldsymbol{K}}$ on domain $K$ such that ${\mathrm{Aut}}({\boldsymbol{K}})=G$.

For every $n>0$, the group $G$ acts on $n^K$ in a natural way: for $g\in G$ and $e\in n^K$ let

For each $n>0$ let $(\mathcal{O}^n_i: i\in I_n)$ be the collection of all orbits of $G{\curvearrowright} n^K$.


Consider now the language $\mathcal{L}=\bigcup_{i=1}^\infty\mathcal{L}^n$, where $\mathcal{L}^n$ in the language that consists of $n$-ary relational symbols $\{O^n_i: i\in I_n\}$, one for every orbit  $\mathcal{O}^n_i$.

nexttext:
It is immediate that $G\subseteq{\mathrm{Aut}}({\boldsymbol{K}})$.  We work now towards the converse inclusion. 


Let $g\in{\mathrm{Aut}}{}({\boldsymbol{K}})$ and let $V(F,U)$ be an open neighborhood of $g$ in ${\mathrm{Homeo}}{}(K)$. We can assume that $U\neq K$.  We will find $h\in G\cap V(F,U)$ which will prove that $G\supseteq{\mathrm{Aut}}({\boldsymbol{K}})$. Because $g(F)$ is compact and $U$ is a union of clopen sets, $g(F)$ can be covered with finitely many of them, so we can assume without loss of generality that $U$ is clopen and $U\neq K$. Notice that $g\in V\big(g^{-1}(U),U\big)\subset V(F,U)$. Consider the following two dual tuples $e_1,e_2\in 2^K$, with $e_1^{-1}(\{0\})=g^{-1}(U)$, $e_1^{-1}(\{1\})= K\setminus g^{-1}(U)$ and $e_2^{-1}(\{0\})= U$, $e_2^{-1}(\{1\})= K\setminus U$. Since $g$ is an automorphism of ${\boldsymbol{K}}$ and since $e_1=g\cdot e_2$, we have that $e_1$ and $e_2$ lie in the same orbit $\mathcal{O}^2_i$ for some $i\in I_2$. Therefore, there is an $h\in G$ that sends $g^{-1}(U)$ into $U$ and therefore $h\in G\cap V(F,U)$, which proves that $G={\mathrm{Aut}}{}({\boldsymbol{K}})$. 



We prove now that ${\boldsymbol{K}}$ is projectively {Fra\"iss\'e}{}. First notice that for every dual tuple $e\in m^K$, there is a unique $i\in I_m$ such that ${\boldsymbol{K}}\models O^m_i(e)$.  Let ${\boldsymbol{C}}\in{\boldsymbol{K}}$ and let $f_1,f_2$ be two epimorphisms of ${\boldsymbol{K}}$ onto ${\boldsymbol{C}}$. We can assume without the loss of generality that $C=\{0,\ldots,m-1\}$ for some $m>0$ and therefore $f_1,f_2\in m^K$. Because $f_1$ and $f_2$ induce the same structure ${\boldsymbol{C}}$, there is a unique $i\in I_m$ such that ${\boldsymbol{K}}\models O^m_i(f_1)$ and ${\boldsymbol{K}}\models O^m_i(f_2)$. Therefore, $f_1$ and $f_2$ lie in the same orbit $G{\curvearrowright} m^K$, so there is $g\in{\mathrm{Aut}}{}({\boldsymbol{K}})$  such that $f_1\circ g=f_2$, showing that ${\boldsymbol{K}}$ is projectively ultra-homogeneous. 
\end{proof}



\section{Turning a structure to a purely dual one}\label{direct to dual}

We  defined our structures so that they carry both dual and direct structure. Here we show that it is always possible to translate the direct structure into a dual one without losing any information. We provide a counterexample to show that the converse is not always possible. From the beginning, therefore, we could have had developed  all of our theory for purely dual topological ${\mathcal{L}}$-structures which seem to be the appropriate structures to consider when working with dual morphisms. However, in Chapter \ref{Compact spaces} it will be convenient to make use of direct relations even if the same things could be done with dual relations only. Moreover, there are many examples of structures whose most natural presentation would involve both direct and dual structure.   



Let ${\mathcal{L}}$ be a language and ${\boldsymbol{M}}$ a topological ${\mathcal{L}}$-structure. Let also $s\in{\mathcal{L}}$ be a direct relation of arity $n$. For every $k$ with $0<k\leq n$ and for every $f\in k^n$ ($f$ is therefore a surjection), we introduce a dual relational symbol $R_s^f$ of arity $k+1$. Let
prevtext:
For each $n>0$ let $(\mathcal{O}^n_i: i\in I_n)$ be the collection of all orbits of $G{\curvearrowright} n^K$.


Consider now the language $\mathcal{L}=\bigcup_{i=1}^\infty\mathcal{L}^n$, where $\mathcal{L}^n$ in the language that consists of $n$-ary relational symbols $\{O^n_i: i\in I_n\}$, one for every orbit  $\mathcal{O}^n_i$.
We turn $K$ into a topological ${\mathcal{L}}$-structure ${\boldsymbol{K}}$. For $e\in m^K$ we let

nexttext:
We turn now ${\boldsymbol{M}}$ into an ${\mathcal{L}}_{\not{s}}$-structure ${\boldsymbol{M}}_{\not{s}}$ on the same domain $M$. We encode $s^{{\boldsymbol{M}}}$ using the new dual symbols as follows: for $f\in k^n$  we let
${\boldsymbol{M}}_{\not{s}}\models R_s^f(\Delta_0,\ldots,\Delta_{k})$,
if and only if there are $a_0,\ldots,a_{n-1}\in M$ such that
prevtext:
It is immediate that $G\subseteq{\mathrm{Aut}}({\boldsymbol{K}})$.  We work now towards the converse inclusion. 


Let $g\in{\mathrm{Aut}}{}({\boldsymbol{K}})$ and let $V(F,U)$ be an open neighborhood of $g$ in ${\mathrm{Homeo}}{}(K)$. We can assume that $U\neq K$.  We will find $h\in G\cap V(F,U)$ which will prove that $G\supseteq{\mathrm{Aut}}({\boldsymbol{K}})$. Because $g(F)$ is compact and $U$ is a union of clopen sets, $g(F)$ can be covered with finitely many of them, so we can assume without loss of generality that $U$ is clopen and $U\neq K$. Notice that $g\in V\big(g^{-1}(U),U\big)\subset V(F,U)$. Consider the following two dual tuples $e_1,e_2\in 2^K$, with $e_1^{-1}(\{0\})=g^{-1}(U)$, $e_1^{-1}(\{1\})= K\setminus g^{-1}(U)$ and $e_2^{-1}(\{0\})= U$, $e_2^{-1}(\{1\})= K\setminus U$. Since $g$ is an automorphism of ${\boldsymbol{K}}$ and since $e_1=g\cdot e_2$, we have that $e_1$ and $e_2$ lie in the same orbit $\mathcal{O}^2_i$ for some $i\in I_2$. Therefore, there is an $h\in G$ that sends $g^{-1}(U)$ into $U$ and therefore $h\in G\cap V(F,U)$, which proves that $G={\mathrm{Aut}}{}({\boldsymbol{K}})$. 



We prove now that ${\boldsymbol{K}}$ is projectively {Fra\"iss\'e}{}. First notice that for every dual tuple $e\in m^K$, there is a unique $i\in I_m$ such that ${\boldsymbol{K}}\models O^m_i(e)$.  Let ${\boldsymbol{C}}\in{\boldsymbol{K}}$ and let $f_1,f_2$ be two epimorphisms of ${\boldsymbol{K}}$ onto ${\boldsymbol{C}}$. We can assume without the loss of generality that $C=\{0,\ldots,m-1\}$ for some $m>0$ and therefore $f_1,f_2\in m^K$. Because $f_1$ and $f_2$ induce the same structure ${\boldsymbol{C}}$, there is a unique $i\in I_m$ such that ${\boldsymbol{K}}\models O^m_i(f_1)$ and ${\boldsymbol{K}}\models O^m_i(f_2)$. Therefore, $f_1$ and $f_2$ lie in the same orbit $G{\curvearrowright} m^K$, so there is $g\in{\mathrm{Aut}}{}({\boldsymbol{K}})$  such that $f_1\circ g=f_2$, showing that ${\boldsymbol{K}}$ is projectively ultra-homogeneous. 
\end{proof}



\section{Turning a structure to a purely dual one}\label{direct to dual}

We  defined our structures so that they carry both dual and direct structure. Here we show that it is always possible to translate the direct structure into a dual one without losing any information. We provide a counterexample to show that the converse is not always possible. From the beginning, therefore, we could have had developed  all of our theory for purely dual topological ${\mathcal{L}}$-structures which seem to be the appropriate structures to consider when working with dual morphisms. However, in Chapter \ref{Compact spaces} it will be convenient to make use of direct relations even if the same things could be done with dual relations only. Moreover, there are many examples of structures whose most natural presentation would involve both direct and dual structure.   



Let ${\mathcal{L}}$ be a language and ${\boldsymbol{M}}$ a topological ${\mathcal{L}}$-structure. Let also $s\in{\mathcal{L}}$ be a direct relation of arity $n$. For every $k$ with $0<k\leq n$ and for every $f\in k^n$ ($f$ is therefore a surjection), we introduce a dual relational symbol $R_s^f$ of arity $k+1$. Let
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex12.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="{\mathcal{L}}_{\not{s}}={\mathcal{L}}\cup\{R_{s}^{f}:\,f\in k^{n}\,\,\,\mbox{%
for some}\,\,\,0<k\leq n\}\setminus\{s\}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">ℒ</mi><mi mathvariant="italic">s̸</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">ℒ</mi><mo>∪</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">{</mo><msubsup><mi>R</mi><mi>s</mi><mi>f</mi></msubsup><mo rspace="4.2pt">:</mo><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>∈</mo><mrow><mpadded width="+5.1pt"><msup><mi>k</mi><mi>n</mi></msup></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mtext>for some</mtext><mo>⁢</mo><mn>   0</mn></mrow><mo><</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>≤</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">}</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>∖</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">{</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">}</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
It can easily be checked that ${\mathrm{Aut}}{}({\boldsymbol{M}})$ can be fully recovered from ${\mathrm{Aut}}{}({\boldsymbol{M}}_{\not{s}})$, that ${\boldsymbol{M}}$ is projectively {Fra\"iss\'e}{} if and only if ${\boldsymbol{M}}_{\not{s}}$ is, and that  ${\mathrm{Aut}}{}({\boldsymbol{M}})$ and ${\mathrm{Aut}}{}({\boldsymbol{M}}_{\not{s}})$ are equal as permutation groups on $M$.  

There are cases of topological ${\mathcal{L}}$-structures which can be turned into purely direct structures. However, this is not the case always. The main observation is that if $r$ is direct relation of arity $k$ which belongs to ${\mathcal{L}}$  and ${\boldsymbol{M}}$ is a topological ${\mathcal{L}}$-structure then $r^{{\boldsymbol{M}}}$ is a set-wise invariant closed subset of $M^k$. Let now $K=2^{\mathbb{N}}$ and let $\mu$ be the uniform probability measure on $2^{\mathbb{N}}$. The group ${\mathrm{Aut}}{}(K,\mu)$ of all continuous measure preserving bijections can be easily seen to be a closed proper subgroup of ${\mathrm{Homeo}}(K)$ which for every $n>0$ leaves no proper subset of $K^n$ invariant. 
Therefore, the canonical {Fra\"iss\'e}{} structure given by an application of Theorem \ref{theorem orbits} on ${\mathrm{Aut}}{}(K,\mu)$ cannot be turned into a purely direct one.

\section{Compact Polish spaces as quotients of dual {Fra\"iss\'e}{} structures}\label{Compact spaces}


We fix a special binary relation symbol $\mathfrak{r}$ whose interpretation will always be a reflexive and symmetric closed relation. A formal relational language ${\mathcal{L}}$ will be decorated with the subscript $\mathfrak{r}$ whenever $\mathfrak{r}\in{\mathcal{L}}_\mathfrak{r}$. Therefore, an ${\mathcal{L}}_\mathfrak{r}$-structure is always going to be a reflexive $\mathfrak{r}$-graph perhaps with some extra structure. We say that an ${\mathcal{L}}_\mathfrak{r}$-structure ${\boldsymbol{K}}$ is a pre-space if $\mathfrak{r}^{{\boldsymbol{K}}}$ is moreover transitive and therefore an equivalence relation.

As we noted in the introduction T. Irwin and S. Solecki used in \cite{Irwin} their notion of projective {Fra\"iss\'e}{} limit to express the pseudo-arc $P$ as a quotient of a projective {Fra\"iss\'e}{} $\{\mathfrak{r}\}$-structure $\mathbb{P}$ via $\mathfrak{r}^{\mathbb{P}}$. Moreover, through their construction, the group ${\mathrm{Aut}}{}(\mathbb{P})$ naturally embedded in ${\mathrm{Homeo}}{}(P)$ as a dense subgroup. In \cite{Camerlo}, R. Camerlo characterized all different projective {Fra\"iss\'e}{} classes\footnote{He allows {Fra\"iss\'e}{} classes to lack hereditary property.} of $\{\mathfrak{r}\}$-structures. Their limits are pre-spaces with quotients $M/\mathfrak{r}^{{\boldsymbol{M}}}$ which vary between certain combinations of singletons, Cantor spaces and  pseudo-arcs \cite{Camerlo}. In \cite{Lelek}, D. Barto\v{s}ov\'{a} and A. Kwiatkowska express the Lelek fan $L$ as the quotient of a the projective {Fra\"iss\'e}{} limit $\mathbb{L}$ of a certain class of directed graphs. Their limit $\mathbb{L}$ can be seen again as pre-space in some ${\mathcal{L}}_\mathfrak{r}$. Here again the group ${\mathrm{Aut}}{}(\mathbb{L})$ naturally embedded in ${\mathrm{Homeo}}{}(L)$ as a dense subgroup.


The purpose of this chapter is to show that under the notion of projective {Fra\"iss\'e}{} limit that we use here the same representation applies to every second-countable compact space $Y$.
Since this is trivial for finite spaces, we will restrict ourselves to the case where $Y$ is infinite. 

The following proposition will be use in the proof of Theorem \ref{compactSpacesMainTheorem}.
\begin{propo}\label{prop_extension}
Let $G,H$ be Polish groups and let $S$ be a dense subgroup of $G$. Then any continuous homomorphism $f:S\to H$ extends to a continuous homomorphism $\tilde{f}:G\to H$. 
\end{propo}

The proof of Proposition \ref{prop_extension} is an easy exercise given that every Polish admits a compatible left-invariant metric $d$ and given this metric we can define a new compatible complete metric $D$ by $D(x,y)=d(x,y)+d(x^{-1},y^{-1})$. For more details see page 6 of \cite{Actions}.

 

\begin{theorem}\label{compactSpacesMainTheorem}
For every second-countable, compact space $Y$ there is a projective {Fra\"iss\'e}{} pre-space ${\boldsymbol{K}}$ such that:

${\boldsymbol{M}}_{\not{s}}\models R_s^f(\Delta_0,\ldots,\Delta_{k})$,
if and only if there are $a_0,\ldots,a_{n-1}\in M$ such that

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex13.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="{\boldsymbol{M}}\models s(a_{0},\ldots,a_{n-1})\,\,\,\mbox{and}\,\,\,a_{i}\in%
\Delta_{f(i)}\,\,\,\mbox{for every}\,\,\,i\in n." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>𝑴</mi><mo>⊧</mo><mrow><mi>s</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>a</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>a</mi><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo rspace="7.6pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+5.1pt"><mtext>and</mtext></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>a</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow><mo>∈</mo><mrow><mpadded width="+5.1pt"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>i</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msub></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+5.1pt"><mtext>for every</mtext></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mi>i</mi></mrow><mo>∈</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
\title{Compact spaces as quotients of projective Fra\"{I}ss\'E limits}

\maketitle
\begin{abstract}
 We develop a theory of projective {Fra\"iss\'e}{} limits in the spirit of Irwin-Solecki, which moreover support a dual structure. Let $K$ be a zero-dimensional, second countable, compact space. We prove that a subgroup $G$ of ${\mathrm{Homeo}}(K)$ is closed in the compact-open topology if and only if it is the automorphism group of some dual topological {Fra\"iss\'e}{} limit ${\boldsymbol{K}}$ on domain $K$.
As an application we prove that every second countable, compact space is the quotient of a projective {Fra\"iss\'e}{} limit ${\boldsymbol{K}}$ with a closed equivalence relation on $K$ that is definable in ${\boldsymbol{K}}$.
\end{abstract}





\section*{Introduction}
The interplay between {Fra\"iss\'e}{} theory and dynamics of non-Archimedean Polish groups established by the correspondence between closed subgroups of $S_\infty$ and countable {Fra\"iss\'e}{} structures has been fruitful in many ways (see for example the survey \cite{survey}). Taking this fact as a departure point it is natural to seek  what would the natural correspondence be for projective {Fra\"iss\'e}{} structures.       

Projective {Fra\"iss\'e}{} structures were first introduced by T. Irwin and S. Solecki in \cite{Irwin}. These are zero-dimensional, compact, topological structures which provide a dual to the classical {Fra\"iss\'e}{} structures. However, the duality in \cite{Irwin} was not explicitly present in the structure as such but rather in the morphisms that were used in the amalgamating process. In the same paper they used the projective limit of finite, reflexive, linear graphs in language ${\mathcal{L}}_R=\{R\}$, where $R$ is a binary relation symbol, to provide a simple description of the unique hereditary, idecomposable, chainable continuum known as the pseudo-arc. This enabled them to deduce new results regarding the pseudo-arc and to show how previously known facts about it (e.g., projective universality and homogeneity) were linked at a deeper level. 


Since then, projective {Fra\"iss\'e}{} constructions were used by several authors in the study of compact spaces and their homeomorphisms groups e.g., \cite{Lelek}, \cite{Ample}, \cite{Large}. There is standard scheme in the analysis that appears in these papers. One starts with a second-countable compact space $Y$ where either $Y$ or the group ${\mathrm{Homeo}}(Y)$ is under investigation. Then one defines an appropriate class ${\mathcal{K}}$ of finite model theoretic ${\mathcal{L}}$-structures  which ``approximate'' $Y$. If this class ${\mathcal{K}}$ satisfies the ``projective {Fra\"iss\'e}{}'' axioms \cite{Irwin} then the projective {Fra\"iss\'e}{} limit ${\boldsymbol{M}}$ of ${\mathcal{K}}$ is uniquely defined. Since the domain $M$ of ${\boldsymbol{M}}$ is a zero-dimensional space one cannot expect to equate it with $Y$ which is in general not zero-dimensional. However, in all the cases cited above the structures appearing in ${\mathcal{K}}$ were classes of graphs perhaps with extra model theoretic structure added on top. The edge relation $R$ was part of the language ${\mathcal{L}}$ and in the limit ${\boldsymbol{M}}$ the relation $R^{{\boldsymbol{M}}}$ always turned out to be an equivalence relation. The quotient ${\boldsymbol{M}}/R^{{\boldsymbol{M}}}$ was equal to $Y$ and the map ${\mathrm{Aut}}({\boldsymbol{M}})\to{\mathrm{Homeo}}(Y)$ that was induced by the quotient was a continuous embedding with dense image in ${\mathrm{Homeo}}(Y)$. This allowed the study of $Y$ and ${\mathrm{Homeo}}(Y)$ via the combinatorial properties of the {Fra\"iss\'e}{} class ${\mathcal{K}}$.

The purpose of this note is to turn this observations to a general method. However, this is not always possible if we insist to use only classical model theoretic structure as done in \cite{Irwin}. We rewrite the theory developed in \cite{Irwin} dualizing it not only in the level of the morphisms but also in the level of structures i.e. we also allow dual predicates in ${\mathcal{L}}$ which quantify over dual tuples (finite clopen partitions). We will call a topological ${\mathcal{L}}$-structure purely dual if ${\mathcal{L}}$ contains only dual predicates.

In Chapter \ref{Chapter_closed_subgroups_of_Homeo} we use a standard orbit completion argument  (i.e., we add extra predicates; one for every orbit) and equipping ${\mathrm{Homeo}}(K)$ with the compact-open topology we get the following result.      

\begin{theorem*}[\textbf{\ref{theorem orbits}}]
Let $G$ be a closed subgroup of ${\mathrm{Homeo}}(K)$ where $K$ is zero-dimensional, compact, second-countable space. Then there is a purely dual projective {Fra\"iss\'e}{} structure ${\boldsymbol{K}}$ on domain $K$ such that ${\mathrm{Aut}}({\boldsymbol{K}})=G$. 
\end{theorem*}   

Theorem \ref{theorem orbits} should be thought of as the dual of the statement that wants every closed subgroup of $S_\infty$ to be the automorphism group of a classical {Fra\"iss\'e}{} limit. In Chapter \ref{direct to dual} we provide a method which allows to turn any topological ${\mathcal{L}}$-structure into a purely dual one without losing any information. We also show  that above theorem is false if we do not allow our structures to support a dual structure. Therefore the context of dual structures is strictly more general then the context of direct structures. 

 In Chapter \ref{Compact spaces} we fix a special binary  relation symbol $\mathfrak{r}$ whose interpretation will always be a reflexive and symmetric closed relation. This should paralleled with the  metric {Fra\"iss\'e}{} theory where the symbol $d$ is  reserved as a signifier for the metric.  A formal relational language ${\mathcal{L}}$ will be decorated with the subscript $\mathfrak{r}$ whenever $\mathfrak{r}$ belongs to ${\mathcal{L}}$. Therefore, we always have  $\mathfrak{r}\in{\mathcal{L}}_\mathfrak{r}$ and ${\mathcal{L}}_\mathfrak{r}$-structures are always in particular reflexive $\mathfrak{r}$-graphs. We say that an ${\mathcal{L}}_\mathfrak{r}$-structure ${\boldsymbol{K}}$ is a pre-space if $\mathfrak{r}^{{\boldsymbol{K}}}$ is moreover transitive and therefore an equivalence relation. We apply Theorem \ref{theorem orbits} to get the following result.

\begin{theorem*}[\textbf{\ref{compactSpacesMainTheorem}}]
For every second-countable, compact space $Y$ there is a projective {Fra\"iss\'e}{} pre-space ${\boldsymbol{K}}$ such that:
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex14.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\big{(}K\big{/}\mathfrak{r}^{{\boldsymbol{K}}}\big{)}\cong_{\mathrm{homeo}}Y." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo maxsize="120%" minsize="120%">(</mo><mrow><mi>K</mi><mo mathsize="120%" stretchy="false">/</mo><msup><mi>𝔯</mi><mi>𝑲</mi></msup></mrow><mo maxsize="120%" minsize="120%">)</mo></mrow><msub><mo>≅</mo><mi>homeo</mi></msub><mi>Y</mi></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: Let $K=\mathrm{S}(\mathcal{F})$ be the Stone space of all ultrafilters $x$ on $\mathcal{F}$. This space comes with a topology whose basic clopen sets can be taken to be the sets of the form $\tilde{F}=\{x : F\in x\}$ for $F\in\mathcal{F}$. The space $K$ is a compact, second-countable, and zero-dimensional. Let $p: K\to Y$ be the natural projection defined by:

The map $p$ is continuous surjection with $p(\tilde{F})=F$ for every $F\in\mathcal{F}$. We can turn now $K$ to a $\{\mathfrak{r}\}$-structure $K_{\mathfrak{r}}$ by setting $K_{\mathfrak{r}}\models \mathfrak{r}(x_0,x_1)$ if and only if $p(x_0)=p(x_1)$. It is immediate that $K_{\mathfrak{r}}$ is a pre-space and that $K/\mathfrak{r}^{K_{\mathfrak{r}}}=Y$.

Notice now that $H$ is acting on $K$ with homeomorphisms: for every $h\in H$ and $x\in K$
prevtext: Let $K=\mathrm{S}(\mathcal{F})$ be the Stone space of all ultrafilters $x$ on $\mathcal{F}$. This space comes with a topology whose basic clopen sets can be taken to be the sets of the form $\tilde{F}=\{x : F\in x\}$ for $F\in\mathcal{F}$. The space $K$ is a compact, second-countable, and zero-dimensional. Let $p: K\to Y$ be the natural projection defined by:

This action is faithful since for every pair $y_0,y_1\in Y$ there are $F_0,F_1\in\mathcal{F}$ such that $y_0\in \mathrm{int}(F_0),y_1\in\mathrm{int}(F_1)$ and $F_0\cap F_1=\emptyset$. Therefore, $H$ embeds into ${\mathrm{Homeo}}(K)$.
 We will denote this copy of $H$ inside ${\mathrm{Homeo}}(K)$ by $H_K$  to distinguish it from $H$ which is a subgroup of ${\mathrm{Homeo}}(Y)$ and we will denote by $T_0$ the inverse of this embedding, i.e.,
prevtext:
The map $p$ is continuous surjection with $p(\tilde{F})=F$ for every $F\in\mathcal{F}$. We can turn now $K$ to a $\{\mathfrak{r}\}$-structure $K_{\mathfrak{r}}$ by setting $K_{\mathfrak{r}}\models \mathfrak{r}(x_0,x_1)$ if and only if $p(x_0)=p(x_1)$. It is immediate that $K_{\mathfrak{r}}$ is a pre-space and that $K/\mathfrak{r}^{K_{\mathfrak{r}}}=Y$.

Notice now that $H$ is acting on $K$ with homeomorphisms: for every $h\in H$ and $x\in K$
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex17.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="h\cdot x=\big{\{}h(F):F\in x\big{\}}\in K." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>h</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo maxsize="120%" minsize="120%">{</mo><mrow><mi>h</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>F</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>:</mo><mrow><mi>F</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow><mo maxsize="120%" minsize="120%">}</mo></mrow><mo>∈</mo><mi>K</mi></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

The map $T_0$ is also continuous. To see that, let $h\in H_K$ and let $V(L,U)$ be an open neighborhood of $T_0(h)$ in ${\mathrm{Homeo}}{}(Y)$, i.e., $T_0(h)(L)\subset U$. Since the family  $\{\mathrm{int}(F): F\in \mathcal{J}\}$  constitutes a basis of $Y$ and since $T_0(h)(L)$ is compact, we can find $F_1,\ldots,F_k\in\mathcal{J}$ such that $T_0(h)(L)\subseteq{}F_1\cup\ldots\cup F_k\subseteq{}U$. Let $F_0=F_1\vee\ldots\vee F_k$, then both $F_0$ and $h^{-1}(F_0)$ belong to $\mathcal{F}$. Moreover, $V(\widetilde{h^{-1}(F_0)},\tilde{F_0})$ is an open neighborhood of $h$ in $H_K$ that is mapped via $T_0$ completely inside $V(L,U)$, proving that $T_0$ is continuous at $h$.  

 By applying the Theorem \ref{theorem orbits}, we can endow $K$ with a topological {Fra\"iss\'e}{} structure ${\boldsymbol{K}}_0$ in a purely dual language ${\mathcal{L}}$, such that $\overline{H_K}={\mathrm{Aut}}{}({\boldsymbol{K}}_0)$ (the closure here is taken in ${\mathrm{Homeo}}{}(K)$). By Proposition \ref{prop_extension} the map $T_0$ extends to a continuous homomorphism $T:{\mathrm{Aut}}{}({\boldsymbol{K}}_0)\to {\mathrm{Homeo}}(Y)$. We denote the image of ${\mathrm{Aut}}{}({\boldsymbol{K}}_0)$ under $T$ by $\hat{H}$. Notice that $\hat{H}$ lies densely in ${\mathrm{Homeo}}{}(K)$ since $H < \hat{H} \le {\mathrm{Homeo}}{}(K)$, and since the same is true for $H$. Moreover, by the density of $H_K$ in $\overline{H_K}$ the continuity of $T$ and the fact that every $F\in\mathcal{F}$ has non-empty interior we get that for every $h\in\overline{H_K}$ and for every $F\in\mathcal{F}$ the following equality holds

The map $T_0$ is also continuous. To see that, let $h\in H_K$ and let $V(L,U)$ be an open neighborhood of $T_0(h)$ in ${\mathrm{Homeo}}{}(Y)$, i.e., $T_0(h)(L)\subset U$. Since the family  $\{\mathrm{int}(F): F\in \mathcal{J}\}$  constitutes a basis of $Y$ and since $T_0(h)(L)$ is compact, we can find $F_1,\ldots,F_k\in\mathcal{J}$ such that $T_0(h)(L)\subseteq{}F_1\cup\ldots\cup F_k\subseteq{}U$. Let $F_0=F_1\vee\ldots\vee F_k$, then both $F_0$ and $h^{-1}(F_0)$ belong to $\mathcal{F}$. Moreover, $V(\widetilde{h^{-1}(F_0)},\tilde{F_0})$ is an open neighborhood of $h$ in $H_K$ that is mapped via $T_0$ completely inside $V(L,U)$, proving that $T_0$ is continuous at $h$.  

 By applying the Theorem \ref{theorem orbits}, we can endow $K$ with a topological {Fra\"iss\'e}{} structure ${\boldsymbol{K}}_0$ in a purely dual language ${\mathcal{L}}$, such that $\overline{H_K}={\mathrm{Aut}}{}({\boldsymbol{K}}_0)$ (the closure here is taken in ${\mathrm{Homeo}}{}(K)$). By Proposition \ref{prop_extension} the map $T_0$ extends to a continuous homomorphism $T:{\mathrm{Aut}}{}({\boldsymbol{K}}_0)\to {\mathrm{Homeo}}(Y)$. We denote the image of ${\mathrm{Aut}}{}({\boldsymbol{K}}_0)$ under $T$ by $\hat{H}$. Notice that $\hat{H}$ lies densely in ${\mathrm{Homeo}}{}(K)$ since $H < \hat{H} \le {\mathrm{Homeo}}{}(K)$, and since the same is true for $H$. Moreover, by the density of $H_K$ in $\overline{H_K}$ the continuity of $T$ and the fact that every $F\in\mathcal{F}$ has non-empty interior we get that for every $h\in\overline{H_K}$ and for every $F\in\mathcal{F}$ the following equality holds
